messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: ğœ†_âˆ & Maximum Variance Embedding: Measuring and Optimizing Connectivity of A Graph Metric

Paper Abstract: Abstract Bobkov, HoudrÃ©, and the last author [BHT00] introduced a PoincarÃ©-type functional parameter, Î»âˆsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\infty}, of a graph G=(V=[n],E)ğºğ‘‰delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ¸G=(V=[n],E). They related Î»âˆsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\infty} to the vertex expansion of the graph via a Cheeger-type inequality, analogous to the inequality relating the spectral gap of the graph, Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2}, to its edge expansion. While Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} can be computed efficiently, our understanding of computational complexity of Î»âˆsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\infty} is relatively little. A work by the second author, Raghavendra, and Vempala [LRV13] related the complexity of Î»âˆsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\infty} to the so-called small-set expansion (SSE) problem, and set forth the desiderata for NP-hardness of this optimization problem. We confirm the conjecture that computing Î»âˆsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\infty} is NP-hard, for weighted trees. Beyond measuring the connectivity of a graph by parameters such as Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} and Î»âˆsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\infty}, in many applications the objective is to optimize connectivity. This, via convex duality, leads to a problem in machine learning, i.e., Maximum Variance Embedding (MVE). The output of MVE is a function from vertices of the input graph G=(V=[n],E)ğºğ‘‰delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ¸G=(V=[n],E) into a low dimensional Euclidean space. The objective is to maximize the variance of the embedding, i.e., sum of pairwise squared Euclidean distances; and the constraints are specific upper, lower, or equality bounds on Euclidean distances between the neighboring vertices. Special cases of Maximum Variance Embedding into â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n} and â„1superscriptâ„1\mathbb{R}^{1} lead to absolute algebraic connectivity [Fie90] and spread constant [ABS98] of the graph metric, that respectively embrace well-connectivity of GğºG and Gnsuperscriptğºğ‘›G^{n}. Beyond connectivity, Maximum Variance Embedding has applications in diffusion speed and robustness of networks, clustering, and dimension reduction. We show that computing Maximum Variance Embedding in tree-width (of the graph) dimensions is NP-hard; accompanied by an efficient distance preserving dimension reduction algorithm with no loss to the variance, given a tree-decomposition and allowing two additional dimensions. We show that MVE of a tree in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} defines a non-convex yet benign optimization landscape, i.e., any local optima is a global optimum. Moreover, we develop a combinatorial algorithm to find such optima in linear time. Finally, we discuss approximate Maximum Variance Embedding being tractable in significantly lower dimensions. For trees and general graphs, for which Maximum Variance Embedding cannot be solved in less than 222 and Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) dimensions, unless P=NPPNP\text{P}=\text{NP}, we provide 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon approximation algorithms for embedding into 111 and Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/Îµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğœ€2O(\log n/\varepsilon^{2}) dimensions, respectively.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "An Asymptotic Isoperimetric Inequality",
        "Î»ğœ†\\lambda1, isoperimetric inequalities for graphs, and superconcentrators",
        "Expander flows, geometric embeddings and graph partitioning",
        "Tree decompositions and social graphs",
        "On non-serial dynamic programming",
        "Fastest mixing markov chain on a graph",
        "lambda infinity, vertex isoperimetry and concentration",
        "A nonlinear programming algorithm for solving semidefinite programs via low-rank factorization",
        "Global optimality of local search for low rank matrix recovery",
        "Convex optimization",
        "Deterministic guarantees for burer-monteiro factorizations of smooth semidefinite programs",
        "Spectral graph theory",
        "A multi-agent coverage algorithm with connectivity maintenance",
        "Spectral properties of hypergraph laplacian and approximation algorithms",
        "Polynomial time guarantees for the burer-monteiro method",
        "Isoperimetric inequalities for cartesian products of graphs",
        "Graph theory 3rd ed",
        "On spectral graph theory in power system restoration",
        "A survey of kernel and spectral methods for clustering",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for minimum weight vertex separators",
        "Algebraic connectivity of graphs",
        "Absolute algebraic connectivity of trees",
        "Some minimax problems for graphs",
        "Embedded in the Shadow of the Separator",
        "Optimal embedding and spectral gap of a finite graph",
        "Rumor spreading and vertex expansion",
        "Expander graphs and their applications",
        "Optimizing the convergence rate of the quantum consensus: A discrete-time model",
        "Minima of functions of several variables with inequalities as side constraints",
        "Reducibility among Combinatorial Problems",
        "Hardness of approximation.",
        "A single-exponential time 2-approximation algorithm for treewidth",
        "Nonlinear programming",
        "Adaptive estimation of a quadratic functional by model selection",
        "The Complexity of Approximating Vertex Expansion",
        "Laplacian matrices of graphs: a survey",
        "Solving sdps for synchronization and maxcut problems via the grothendieck inequality",
        "Mathematical aspects of mixing times in markov chains",
        "Comparison of Metric Spectral Gaps",
        "Introductory lectures on convex optimization: A basic course",
        "Interior-Point Polynomial Algorithms in Convex Programming",
        "On the structure of k-trees",
        "Convex analysis",
        "Graph minors. ii. algorithmic aspects of tree-width",
        "Graph Expansion and the Unique Games Conjecture",
        "Reductions between expansion problems",
        "The Fastest Mixing Markov Process on a Graph and a Connection to a Maximum Variance Unfolding Problem",
        "Personal communication",
        "Maximizing the algebraic connectivity in multilayer networks with arbitrary interconnections",
        "On nonlinear dimensionality reduction, linear smoothing and autoencoding",
        "An introduction to nonlinear dimensionality reduction by maximum variance unfolding",
        "Learning a kernel matrix for nonlinear dimensionality reduction",
        "Local graph clustering beyond cheegerâ€™s inequality"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in ğœ†_âˆ & Maximum Variance Embedding: Measuring and Optimizing Connectivity of A Graph Metric, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
